docs.title: Welcome to Biology Problems
docs.text: Explore free and open problem sets for Biochemistry, Genetics, and more! Click on a subject to get started.

docs.title: Subjects
docs.text:
• Biochemistry
  • Genetics

docs.title: List of Biochemistry Topics
docs.text: Explore the foundational concepts and techniques in Biochemistry. Click on a topic to dive deeper.

docs.title: Topics
docs.text:
1. The Molecular Design of Life

    • Molecular design of life, major elements, and biomacromolecules.

  2. Water Chemistry and pH

    • Properties of water, pH scales, buffering systems.

  3. Amino Acids

    • Amino acid structure, types, and roles in protein structure.

  4. Proteins: Structure and Folding

    • Protein folding, structural levels, and mechanisms.

  5. Protein Purification Techniques

    • Isolation and analysis methods, chromatography, electrophoresis.

  6. Enzymes and Thermodynamics

    • Enzyme classifications, kinetics, thermodynamic principles.

  7. Enzyme Regulation

    • Enzyme inhibition, covalent modifications, ligand-protein interactions.

  8. Carbohydrates

    • Carbohydrate structure, glycosidic bonds, biological roles.

  9. Nucleic Acids

    • Nucleotide structure, DNA/RNA functions, biotechnology applications.

docs.title: Topic 1: The Molecular Design of Life
docs.text: Molecular design of life, major elements, and biomacromolecules.

docs.title: Hydrophobicity Based on Molecular Formula
docs.text:
Download the original question set

Based on their molecular formula, which one of the following compounds is most likely hydrophobic?
  • A. ammonia, NH3
  • B. erythrose, C4H8O4
  • C. methanol, CH3OH 
  • D. phosphoric acid, H3PO4
  • E. butane, CH3CH2CH2CH3
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 2: Water Chemistry and pH
docs.text: Properties of water, pH scales, buffering systems.

docs.title: pH Values Outside Optimal Buffering Range Based on pKa
docs.text:
Download the original question set

Phosphoric acid and its conjugate base, phosphate, is abbreviated Pi and is formed by cells from the hydrolysis of ATP into ADP.Phosphoric acid is triprotic with pKa values of 2.16, 7.21, and 12.32.Which one of the following pH values falls outside the optimal buffering rangeof Phosphoric acid?

  • A. pH 2.7
  • B. pH 8.0
  • C. pH 10.6
  • D. pH 11.7
  • E. pH 13.2
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Protonation State Based on pH and pKa Values
docs.text:
Download the original question set

Oxalic acid and its conjugate base, oxalate, is found in many plants and vegetables and is a product of metabolic processes.Oxalic acid is diprotic with pKa values of 1.27 and 4.28.Oxalic acid has three possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 5.0?

  • A. (COOH)2
  • B. (HOOC)COO-
  • C. (COO)22-
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Protonation State Based on pH
docs.text:
Download the original question set

Arsenic acid and its conjugate base, arsenate, is extremely toxic, corrosive, and carcinogenic; it serves as a precursor to a variety of pesticides.Arsenic acid is triprotic with pKa values of 2.19, 6.94, and 11.50.Arsenic acid has four possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 8.5?

  • A. H3AsO4
  • B. H2AsO4-
  • C. HAsO42-
  • D. AsO43-
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Protonation State Based on pH and pKa Values
docs.text:
Download the original question set

Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid and its conjugate base, EDTA, is commonly used in chelation therapy and as a chelating agent in biochemical experiments..Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid is tetraprotic with pKa values of 2.00, 2.67, 6.16, and 10.26.Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid has five possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 4.5?

  • A. C10H12N2O84-
  • B. C10H13N2O83-
  • C. C10H14N2O82-
  • D. C10H15N2O8-
  • E. C10H16N2O8
Check Answer
